--- title: "üóìÔ∏è Session 10: Data preparation" date: "2024-05-03" date-modified: last-modified --- In this session you learn how to turn your raw data into a state such that you can work with it. Luckily, there is one particular form for our data that represents the common starting point for all further operations, such as visualization or modelling. This form is called *tidy data*. And the goal of this session is to equip you with the tools that you need to turn the often messy raw data into tidy data. These skills are important because they make you independent: you will be able to prepare any data you find or create yourself such that you can further process it, and you will not rely on others to provide you data in a particular form. ## üë®‚Äçüè´ Lecture Slides Either click on the slide area below or click [here](/2024Spring/material/slides/T10-DataPreparation.pdf) to download the slides. ```{=html}
``` ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Data and solutions to the intermediate exercises - [Data used in the video](DataWranglingVideo.zip) - [Data for exercises](DataPrepExData.zip) ::: ## üé• Lecture videos All the videos are available via this [playlist](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLZDawQMrG1RIzp07hiVKmu6wUs8tqdKod). ::: {.callout-note collapse="true"} ## Expand to access the videos directly ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Solutions to the intermediate exercises ::: ## üìö Mandatory Reading - The tutorial [Data preparation](/2024Spring/tutorials/data-wrangling/index.qmd) - [Chapter 5](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/data-tidy.html) in @r4ds. ## Further Reading - The help page for the [selection helpers](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/select.html), which facilitate the selection of particular columns. - [Chapter 13](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/numbers) in @r4ds. - [Chapter 14](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/strings) in @r4ds. - @tidydata on the concept of 'tidy data' (see the [Github repo](https://github.com/hadley/tidy-data) for reproduction of the paper) ## ‚úçÔ∏è Coursework - Do the exercises `Wrangling1` from the `DataScienceExercises` package ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Quick code for starting the exercises ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} learnr::run_tutorial( name = "Wrangling1", package = "DataScienceExercises", shiny_args=list("launch.browser"=TRUE)) ``` ::: ::: - Download data about the CO2 emissions for some countries of your choice from the World Bank [website](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EN.ATM.CO2E.PC) for the years 2000 to 2020. Set up an R project, save the data, import it, and make a line graph. - [ZIP file](/2024Spring/material/session10-solution.zip) with a possible solution^[You can ignore the `make_co2_data.R` for now and only look at `make_co2_plot.R`.] - If you want more exercises on the challenge of making data longer/wider, you can do the exercises `Wrangling2` from the `DataScienceExercises` package ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Quick code for starting the exercises ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} learnr::run_tutorial( name = "Wrangling2", package = "DataScienceExercises", shiny_args=list("launch.browser"=TRUE)) ``` ::: :::
